item.title: UK airlines told to avoid Belarusian airspace after journalist arrest
item.description: Britain says carriers should by-pass Belarus after a flight was diverted to Minsk and a journalist held.

item.title: Max Mosley: Privacy campaigner and ex-motorsport boss dies at 81
item.description: The president of the FIA governing body from 1993 to 2009 was also a prominent privacy campaigner.

item.title: Algae proteins partially restore man's sight
item.description: The patient was completely blind before the treatment - now he can see and count objects on a table.

item.title: Heysham explosion: Cut gas pipe caused fatal blast, say police
item.description: Two-year-old George Hinds died in the explosion in Heysham, Lancashire, on 16 May.

item.title: Covid-19: Shops see 30% fewer customers and three-year waits for an NHS dentist
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Monday evening.

item.title: Sasha Johnson: Black Lives Matter activist shot in London
item.description: Sasha Johnson has been described as a "powerful voice" who has always campaigned for black people.

item.title: Eight arrests in Royal Mail text scam investigation
item.description: One man is charged following dawn raids in London, Coventry, Birmingham and Essex.

item.title: BBC to review editorial policies and Martin Bashir hiring
item.description: A review is announced after the inquiry into the 1995 BBC interview with Diana, Princess of Wales.

item.title: Parents fear for pupils' mental state at £53,000 fee school
item.description: Councils fund places at the specialist school in Hackney for pupils with autism and behavioural issues.

item.title: Indian couple holds mid-air wedding 'to escape Covid restrictions'
item.description: The nuptials reportedly took place at the same time as India's official death toll passed 300,000.

item.title: Pollution: ‘We can smell and taste the traffic at school'
item.description: A primary school in Manchester sits on one of Europe's busiest roads where particle pollution levels exceed WHO limits.

item.title: Damiano David: Eurovision winner cleared of drug use by broadcaster
item.description: A test clears Måneskin's lead singer of drug use during the competition's grand final.

item.title: George Floyd death: How do I talk to my son about race?
item.description: A year on from the death of George Floyd, BBC presenter Eddie Nestor examines his role as a father.

item.title: Trafalgar Square Fourth Plinth: Shortlist announced
item.description: The Fourth Plinth in Trafalgar Square is home to a rolling commission of artworks.

item.title: Billboard Music Awards: Drake's son joins him to accept artist of the decade
item.description: The star brings his tearful three-year-old on stage as he accepts a prize for artist of the decade.

item.title: Charlie Bit My Finger video to be taken off YouTube after selling for £500,000
item.description: The piece of internet history will now be taken off YouTube, after more than 880 million views.

item.title: Former miner: Why I’m giving up my coal fire
item.description: Stan Renton and his wife Audrey, have been heating their home with coal for their entire married lives.

item.title: The couple who met on YouTube
item.description: Australian Anitha Kannan and Ian Chalmers, from the UK, met over YouTube and bonded over social anxiety in lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus: Training dogs to identify the scent of Covid-19
item.description: Trials are underway with dogs trained to sniff out the coronavirus. If the trails are successful, dogs could aid efforts to prevent super-spreading in busy areas.

item.title: Who could represent the UK at the Eurovision Song Contest 2022?
item.description: Could Bill Bailey, some drag queens, a rock band, a bhangra act or Ed Sheeran restore some pride?

item.title: Belarus Ryanair flight diverted: Passengers describe panic on board
item.description: Those on board describe a "sudden dive" as the aircraft changed course due to a reported bomb threat.

item.title: Children tell of neglect, filth and fear in US asylum camps
item.description: The BBC has uncovered allegations of cold temperatures, sickness, lice and abuse, through a series of interviews with children and staff at US detention camps for children.

item.title: Bob Dylan: 80 things you may not know about him on his 80th birthday
item.description: A look back at the life and career of the influential and now-octogenarian singer-songwriter.

item.title: Derbyshire widow's plea for rule change on overloaded lorries
item.description: Denise Oscroft calls for change after seeing her husband Steven killed by a lump of concrete.

item.title: Toronto lockdown - one of the world's longest?
item.description: What is the effect of one of the longest pandemic indoor-dining bans in the world?

item.title: Israel-Gaza: How much money does Israel get from the US?
item.description: Israel gets billions of dollars in US aid - we look at why, and what that money is used for.

item.title: Why Indonesia's 'new Bali' is accused of trampling on human rights
item.description: Indonesia hopes for tourism but UN experts and locals allege land grabbing and rights violations.

item.title: Guardiola 'could not care less' Lahoz will referee Champions League final
item.description: Pep Guardiola has not thought about Antonio Mateu Lahoz refereeing the Champions League final despite his history with the official.

item.title: Who impressed and who fell short? Our club-by-club Premier League assessment
item.description: BBC Sport's chief football writer Phil McNulty assess each Premier League club's season - and looks back at his predictions.

item.title: Premier League predictions 2020-21: How accurate were the BBC Sport pundits?
item.description: Twenty-five BBC pundits predicted who would win the 2020-21 Premier League title and finish in the top four - how did they get on?

item.title: Mercedes could protest over flex-wings in Baku
item.description: Mercedes refuse to rule out lodging a protest if rival teams run flexible rear wings at the forthcoming Azerbaijan Grand Prix.

item.title: Ramos left out of Spain's Euro 2020 squad as Laporte called up
item.description: Sergio Ramos is left out of Spain's Euro 2020 squad, but boss Luis Enrique includes Manchester City defender Aymeric Laporte.

item.title: Andre Villas-Boas on his World Rally Championship debut - 'I was scared of the big jump'
item.description: A "very happy" former Chelsea and Tottenham manager Andre Villas-Boas jokes he was scared by the iconic 'Fafe' jump on his World Rally Championship debut in Portugal.

item.title: Diego Simeone's young daughter sings Atletico Madrid chant during interview
item.description: Diego Simeone's young daughter interrupts an interview to sing an Atletico Madrid song with her dad.

item.title: Covid: Who has to self-isolate and for how long?
item.description: The length of quarantine has changed for contacts and people arriving from abroad.

item.title: Covid Indian variant: Where is it, how does it spread and is it more infectious?
item.description: The Indian variant is spreading in some parts of the country - how serious is it?

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Lockdown restrictions will ease in Northern Ireland, following rule changes in England, Scotland and Wales

item.title: Covid: How should I protect myself from Covid now?
item.description: What are the actions we can take to reduce our risk of catching the virus?

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Foreign holidays are now possible, but travellers must follow strict rules on their return.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk of Covid on public transport?
item.description: As UK coronavirus restrictions are relaxed, public transport could become much busier.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go.... and who with?
item.description: The rules on having a holiday in the UK have been relaxed - but restrictions remain.

item.title: What are the new rules for social distancing?
item.description: Guidance on hugging close friends and family is being relaxed in England and Scotland.

item.title: Can two households travel in one car? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The pandemic has seen many people lose their jobs - but not as many as expected

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and can I hold a reception?
item.description: Restrictions on weddings have been eased across the UK - so how can you now celebrate?

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Restaurants and pubs are reopening inside, but what are the rules?
item.description: Pubs have reopened inside, but there are still Covid rules for customers to follow.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 37 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Lockdown easing: Virus experts tell us what they will (and won't) be doing
item.description: How will scientists use their new-found freedoms when Covid restrictions are eased on Monday?

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People in their 20s and 30s are now being offered a Covid vaccine as the UK rollout continues.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: Covid inquiry: What is it and how will it work?
item.description: An independent public inquiry has been announced, but how will it work?

item.title: Covid-19 vaccines: Why some African states can't use their vaccines
item.description: African countries have struggled to get vaccines, but some now plan to throw away thousands of doses.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Rules are relaxing, but masks are still needed in some settings - here's where and why.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel in various parts of the UK are being urged to get a Covid test.

item.title: What are the India, Brazil, South Africa and UK variants?
item.description: In some parts of the UK coronavirus cases are rising due to a variant from India that spreads more easily.

item.title: Covid: What refund rights are there for holidays abroad?
item.description: Quarantine-free overseas holidays will be possible after 17 May, but what rights do you have if plans or rules change?

item.title: Covid-19: Five ways to make hugging safer, from the experts
item.description: Millions of people will be able to hug loved ones again from Monday. But can you minimise the risk?

item.title: India variant: Why was India not put on the red list sooner?
item.description: India was put on the travel ban list two weeks after Pakistan and Bangladesh.

item.title: Indian variant: What's causing the spike in Bolton?
item.description: The town has seen a sharp spike in Covid cases - driven by the emergence of the Indian variant.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Martin Bashir inquiry: Diana, the reporter and the BBC
item.description: The full story of how the BBC's Martin Bashir got his 1995 interview with Princess Diana - and what happened next.

item.title: The black children wrongly sent to 'special' schools in the 1970s
item.description: In the '60s and '70s, black children were wrongly sent to schools for the "educationally subnormal".

item.title: Uyghur imams targeted in China's Xinjiang crackdown
item.description: China has targeted Muslim religious leaders, according to a new report, charging many with extremism.

item.title: 'Talk to me': A train driver asking men to open up
item.description: A tragedy inspired Scotland's only woman freight train driver to get men talking about mental health.

item.title: Chinese dreams on Native American land: A tale of cannabis boom and bust
item.description: How the pandemic cannabis boom led to chaos on the Navajo Nation, pitting two minorities against each other.
